children.value: In this chapter, we look at oscillating systems that undergo “simple harmonic motion”, such as the motion of a mass attached to a spring. Many systems in the physical world, such as an oscillating pendulum, can be described by the same mathematical formalism that describes the motion of a mass attached to a spring.
Understand how to model the position, velocity, and acceleration of a mass attached to a spring.
Understand the conditions under which a system undergoes simple harmonic motion.
Understand how to model the motion of a pendulum when it undergoes simple harmonic motion.
What do the motion of a mass attached to a spring, a cork bobbing in the water, and a pendulum have in common?
The motion of a spring-mass system

children.label: The motion of a spring-mass system

children.value: As an example of simple harmonic motion, we first consider the motion of a block of mass

children.html: mmm

children.value: that can slide without friction along a horizontal surface. The mass is attached to a spring with spring constant

children.html: kkk

children.value: which is attached to a wall on the other end. We introduce a one-dimensional coordinate system to describe the position of the mass, such that the

children.html: xxx

children.value: axis is co-linear with the motion, the origin is located where the spring is at rest, and the positive direction corresponds to the spring being extended. This “spring-mass system” is illustrated in

children.alt: A horizontal spring-mass system oscillating about the origin with an amplitude $A$.

children.value: A horizontal spring-mass system oscillating about the origin with an amplitude

children.html: AAA

children.value: We assume that the force exerted by the spring on the mass is given by Hooke’s Law:

children.html: F⃗=−kxx^\vec F = -kx \hat xF=−kxx^
xxx

children.value: is the position of the mass. The only other forces exerted on the mass are its weight and the normal force from the horizontal surface, which are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. Therefore, the net force on the mass is the force from the spring.
, if the spring is compressed  (or extended) by a distance

children.html: AAA

children.value: relative to the rest position, and the mass is then released, the mass will oscillate back and forth between

children.html: x=±Ax=\pm Ax=±A
AAA

children.value: the “amplitude of the motion”. When the mass is at

children.html: x=±Ax=\pm Ax=±A

children.value: , its speed is zero, as these points correspond to the location where the mass “turns around”.
We can describe the motion of the mass using energy, since the mechanical energy of the mass is conserved. At any position,

children.html: xxx
EEE

children.value: , of the mass will have a term from the potential energy,

children.html: UUU

children.value: , associated with the spring force, and kinetic energy,

children.html: KKK
E=U+K=12kx2+12mv2E = U + K =\frac{1}{2}kx^2 + \frac{1}{2}mv^2E=U+K=21​kx2+21​mv2

children.value: We can find the mechanical energy,

children.html: EEE

children.value: , by evaluating the energy at one of the turning points. At these points, the  kinetic energy of the mass is zero, so

children.html: E=U(x=A)=1/2kA2E=U(x=A)=1/2kA^2E=U(x=A)=1/2kA2

children.value: . We can then write the expression for mechanical energy as:

children.html: 12kx2+12mv2=12kA2\boxed{\frac{1}{2}kx^2 + \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}kA^2}21​kx2+21​mv2=21​kA2​

children.value: We can thus always know the speed,

children.html: vvv

children.value: , of the mass at any position,

children.html: xxx
AAA
v(x)=k(A2−x2)mv(x) = \sqrt{\frac{k(A^2-x^2)}{m}}v(x)=mk(A2−x2)​​

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)
v(t)v(t)v(t)

children.value: , of the mass as a function of time. The

children.html: xxx

children.value: component of Newton’s Second Law for the mass attached to the spring can be written:

children.html: ∑Fx=−kx=ma\sum F_x = -kx = ma∑Fx​=−kx=ma

children.value: We can write the acceleration in Newton’s Second Law more explicitly as the second derivative of the position,

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)

children.value: , with respect to time. If we do this, we can see that Newton’s Second Law for the mass attached to the spring is a differential equation for the function

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)

children.label: eq:simpleharmonicmotion:shmspring
children.html: ma=−kxmd2xdt2=−kx∴d2xdt2=−kmx\begin{align*} ma &= -kx\nonumber\\ m\frac{d^2x}{dt^2} &= -kx\nonumber\\ \therefore \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} &= -\frac{k}{m}x \end{align*}mamdt2d2x​∴dt2d2x​​=−kx=−kx=−mk​x​

children.value: We want to find the position function,

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)

children.value: . Equation {\ref{eq:simpleharmonicmotion:shmspring}} tells us that the second derivative of

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)

children.value: with respect to time must equal the negative of the

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)
k/mk/mk/m

children.value: . Without having taken a course on differential equations, it might not be obvious what the function

children.html: x(t)x(t)x(t)

children.value: could be. Several, equivalent functions can satisfy this equation. One possible choice, which we present here as a guess, is\footnote{Other possible guesses that work are

children.html: Asin⁡(ωt+ϕ)A \sin(\omega t + \phi)Asin(ωt+ϕ)
x(t)=Acos⁡(ωt)+Bsin⁡(ωt)x(t) = A\cos(\omega t) + B\sin(\omega t)x(t)=Acos(ωt)+Bsin(ωt)
x(t)=Acos⁡(ωt+ϕ)\boxed{x(t) = A \cos(\omega t + \phi)}x(t)=Acos(ωt+ϕ)​
AAA

children.value: are constants that we need to determine. We can take the second order derivative with respect to time of the function above to verify that it indeed “solves” the differential equation:

x(t) &= A \cos(\omega t + \phi)\\
\frac{d}{dt}x(t) &= -A\omega\sin(\omega t + \phi)\\
\frac{d^2}{dt^2}x(t) &=\frac{d}{dt}\left( -A\omega\sin(\omega t + \phi)\right)= -A\omega^2\cos(\omega t + \phi)\\
\therefore \frac{d^2}{dt^2}x(t) &= - \omega^2 x(t)
children.html: x(t)=Acos⁡(ωt+ϕ)ddtx(t)=−Aωsin⁡(ωt+ϕ)d2dt2x(t)=ddt(−Aωsin⁡(ωt+ϕ))=−Aω2cos⁡(ωt+ϕ)∴d2dt2x(t)=−ω2x(t)\begin{align*} x(t) &= A \cos(\omega t + \phi)\\ \frac{d}{dt}x(t) &= -A\omega\sin(\omega t + \phi)\\ \frac{d^2}{dt^2}x(t) &=\frac{d}{dt}\left( -A\omega\sin(\omega t + \phi)\right)= -A\omega^2\cos(\omega t + \phi)\\ \therefore \frac{d^2}{dt^2}x(t) &= - \omega^2 x(t) \end{align*}x(t)dtd​x(t)dt2d2​x(t)∴dt2d2​x(t)​=Acos(ωt+ϕ)=−Aωsin(ωt+ϕ)=dtd​(−Aωsin(ωt+ϕ))=−Aω2cos(ωt+ϕ)=−ω2x(t)​

children.value: It should now be clear why
is called the angular frequency, since it is related to the frequency of the motion.
In order to double the oscillation period of a spring-mass system, you can
double the ratio of the mass over the spring constant.
We can make an analogy between the mathematical description of the motion of a spring-mass system and that of uniform circular motion. Consider a particle that is moving along a circle of radius

Since the speed is constant, the balls are evenly spaced out around the circle. At the bottom of the figure, you can see what it would look like if we only considered the motion in the

children.html: xxx

children.html: yyy

children.html: mmm

children.value: is zero. The only forces exerted on the mass are the force from the spring and its weight. The condition for the equilibrium is thus:

\sum F_y = F_g - F(y_0) &=0\\
 mg - ky_0 &= 0 \\
 \therefore mg &= ky_0
children.html: ∑Fy=Fg−F(y0)=0mg−ky0=0∴mg=ky0\begin{align*} \sum F_y = F_g - F(y_0) &=0\\ mg - ky_0 &= 0 \\ \therefore mg &= ky_0 \end{align*}∑Fy​=Fg​−F(y0​)mg−ky0​∴mg​=0=0=ky0​​

children.value: Now, consider the forces on the mass at some position

children.html: yyy

children.value: when the spring is extended downwards relative to the equilibrium position (right panel of
). Newton’s Second Law at that position can be written as:

\sum F_y = mg - ky &= ma\\
\therefore m \frac{d^2y}{dt^2}& = mg - ky
children.html: ∑Fy=mg−ky=ma∴md2ydt2=mg−ky\begin{align*} \sum F_y = mg - ky &= ma\\ \therefore m \frac{d^2y}{dt^2}& = mg - ky \end{align*}∑Fy​=mg−ky∴mdt2d2y​​=ma=mg−ky​

children.value: Note that the net force on the mass will always be in the direction so as to “restore” the position of the mass back to the equilibrium position,

children.html: y0y_0y0​

children.html: y0y_0y0​

children.value: , the net force would be downwards.
We can substitute the equilibrium condition,

children.html: mg=ky0mg = ky_0mg=ky0​

children.value: , into the equation that we obtained from Newton’s Second Law:

m \frac{d^2y}{dt^2}& = mg - ky \\
m \frac{d^2y}{dt^2}&= ky_0 - ky\\
m \frac{d^2y}{dt^2}&=-k(y-y_0) \\
\therefore \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} &= -\frac{k}{m}(y-y_0)

children.value: This is the same equation as that for the simple harmonic motion of a horizontal spring-mass system
origin located at the equilibrium position

instead of at the rest length of the spring. In other words, a vertical spring-mass system will undergo simple harmonic motion in the vertical direction about the equilibrium position. In general, a spring-mass system will undergo simple harmonic motion if a constant force that is co-linear with the spring force is exerted on the mass (in this case, gravity). That motion will be centred about a point of equilibrium where the net force on the mass is zero rather than where the spring is at its rest position.
How does the period of motion of a vertical spring-mass system compare to the period of a horizontal system (assuming the mass and spring constant are the same)?
The period of the vertical system will be larger.
The period of the vertical system will be smaller.
The period will be the same.

children.html: −k1(x−x1)+k2(x2−x)=ma−k1x+k1x1+k2x2−k2x=md2xdt2−(k1+k2)x+k1x1+k2x2=md2xdt2\begin{align*} -k_1(x-x_1) + k_2 (x_2 - x) &= m a \\ -k_1x +k_1x_1 + k_2 x_2 - k_2 x &= m \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}\\ -(k_1+k_2)x + k_1x_1 + k_2 x_2&= m \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} \end{align*}−k1​(x−x1​)+k2​(x2​−x)−k1​x+k1​x1​+k2​x2​−k2​x−(k1​+k2​)x+k1​x1​+k2​x2​​=ma=mdt2d2x​=mdt2d2x​​

−(k1+k2)x+k1x1+k2x2=md2xdt2−(k1+k2)x+(k1+k2)x0=md2xdt2∴−(k1+k2)(x−x0)=md2xdt2\begin{align*} -(k_1+k_2)x + k_1x_1 + k_2 x_2&= m \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}\\ -(k_1+k_2)x + (k_1+k_2)x_0&= m \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}\\ \therefore -(k_1+k_2) (x-x_0) &= m \frac{d^2x}{dt^2} \end{align*}−(k1​+k2​)x+k1​x1​+k2​x2​−(k1​+k2​)x+(k1​+k2​)x0​∴−(k1​+k2​)(x−x0​)​=mdt2d2x​=mdt2d2x​=mdt2d2x​​
k=k1+k2k=k_1+k_2k=k1​+k2​

children.value: as the “effective” spring constant from the two springs combined. We can also define a new coordinate,

children.value: We then saw that the motion of a vertical spring-mass system, as well as that of a mass attached to two springs, could also be described by
. Any physical system that can described by
is said to undergo “simple harmonic motion”, or to be a “simple harmonic oscillator”. If we find that the physical model of a system leads to
, then we immediately know that the position of system can be described by

The key physical characteristic of a simple harmonic oscillator is that there is a “restoring force” whose magnitude is proportional to the displacement from the equilibrium position. A restoring force is a force that acts to place the system back in equilibrium, and is thus always in the direction that is opposite of the displacement relative to an equilibrium position. In the three systems that we considered so far, the net force on the mass was always such that it would restore the mass back to the equilibrium position, where the net force on the mass is zero.

Many systems in nature are well modelled as simple harmonic oscillators. Some examples are: the motion of a pendulum as it oscillates, the motion of a buoy bobbing up and down in the sea, the motion of electrons in a shorted capacitor, and the vibrations of atoms in a molecule.
In this section, we show how and when the motion of a pendulum can be described as simple harmonic motion. Consider the simple pendulum that is constructed from a mass-less string of length,

children.html: LLL

children.value: , attached to a fixed point on one end and to a point mass

children.html: mmm

children.value: on the other, as illustrated in

children.alt: A simple pendulum which oscillates in a vertical plane.

children.value: A simple pendulum which oscillates in a vertical plane.
The pendulum can swing in the vertical plane, and we have shown our choice of coordinate system (the

children.html: zzz

children.value: axis, not shown, is out of the page). The only two forces on the mass are the tension from the string and its weight. We can describe the position of the mass by the angle,

children.html: θ(t)\theta(t)θ(t)

children.value: , that the string makes with the vertical. We can model the dynamics of the simple pendulum by considering the net torque and angular acceleration about the axis of rotation that is perpendicular to the plane of the page and that goes through the point on the string that is fixed.

The force of tension cannot create a torque on the mass about the axis of rotation, as it is anti-parallel to the vector from the point of rotation to the mass. The net torque is thus the torque from the force of gravity:

\vec\tau^{net} &=\vec \tau_g \\
&=\vec r \times \vec F_g = (L\sin\theta \hat x - L\cos\theta \hat y) \times (-mg\hat y)\\
&=-mgL\sin\theta \hat z

children.value: Kaiden built a grandfather clock using a simple pendulum, but he found that the period was twice as large as as he wanted it to be. In order to halve the period of the pendulum, he can
halve the length of the string.

A physical pendulum is defined as any object that is allowed to rotate in the vertical plane about some axis that goes through the object, as illustrated in

children.alt: A physical pendulum which oscillates in a vertical plane about an axis through the object.

children.value: A physical pendulum which oscillates in a vertical plane about an axis through the object.

The only forces exerted on the pendulum are its weight (exerted at its centre of mass) and a contact force exerted at the axis of rotation. The physical pendulum can be modelled in exactly the same way as the simple pendulum, except that we use the moment of inertia of the object about the axis of rotation. Only the weight results in a torque about the rotation axis, since the contact force is exerted at the rotation axis:

children.html: τnet=τg=Iα−mghsin⁡θ=Iα=Id2θdt2\begin{align*} \tau^{net} = \tau_g &= I\alpha\\ -mgh\sin\theta &= I\alpha = I \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} \end{align*}τnet=τg​−mghsinθ​=Iα=Iα=Idt2d2θ​​
hhh

children.value: is the distance from the axis of rotation to the centre of mass. In the small angle approximation, this becomes:

children.html: d2θdt2=−mghIθ(for small θ)\begin{align*} \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} &=-\frac{mgh}{I}\theta \quad (\text{for small }\theta) \end{align*}dt2d2θ​​=−Imgh​θ(for small θ)​

children.value: and we find that the physical pendulum oscillates with an angular frequency:

children.html: ω=mghI\omega = \sqrt{\frac{mgh}{I}}ω=Imgh​​

children.value: A simple harmonic oscillator will always oscillate about an equilibrium position, where the net force on the oscillator is zero. The net force on a simple harmonic oscillator is always directed towards the equilibrium position, and has a magnitude proportional to the distance of the oscillator from its equilibrium position. The force is called a restoring force. A vertical spring-mass system, and a mass attached to two springs will both undergo simple harmonic motion about their respective equilibrium position.

A simple pendulum will undergo simple harmonic oscillations, if the amplitude of the oscillations is small. The angular frequency for the oscillations of a simple pendulum only depends on the length of the pendulum:

children.html: ω=gL\omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{L}}ω=Lg​​

A torsional pendulum consists of a horizontal rod suspended from a vertical wire. When the rod is rotated so that it is displaced an angle
from equilibrium, the wire (which is now twisted) provides a restoring torque about the axis of the wire given by:

md2xdt2=(k1+k2)x0−(k1+k2)xd2xdt2=(k1+k2)m(x0−x)d2xdt2=−(k1+k2)m(x−x0)\begin{align*} m\frac{d^2x}{dt^2}&=(k_1+k_2)x_0-(k_1+k_2)x\\ \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}&=\frac{(k_1+k_2)}{m}(x_0-x)\\ \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}&=-\frac{(k_1+k_2)}{m}(x-x_0)\\ \end{align*}mdt2d2x​dt2d2x​dt2d2x​​=(k1​+k2​)x0​−(k1​+k2​)x=m(k1​+k2​)​(x0​−x)=−m(k1​+k2​)​(x−x0​)​

children.value: . Because this is simple harmonic motion, we know that the position of the platform can be described by the following function:

t=0t=0t=0

x′(0)=Acos⁡(ω(0)+ϕ)A=Acos⁡(ϕ)1=cos⁡(ϕ)∴ϕ=0\begin{align*} x'(0)&= A \cos(\omega (0) + \phi)\\ A&= A \cos(\phi)\\ 1&=\cos(\phi)\\ \therefore \phi&=0 \end{align*}x′(0)A1∴ϕ​=Acos(ω(0)+ϕ)=Acos(ϕ)=cos(ϕ)=0​
v(t)=ddtx(t)=−Aωsin⁡(ωt+ϕ)=−Aωsin⁡(ωt)\begin{align*} v(t)=\frac{d}{dt}x(t) &= -A\omega\sin(\omega t + \phi)\\ &=-A\omega\sin(\omega t) \end{align*}v(t)=dtd​x(t)​=−Aωsin(ωt+ϕ)=−Aωsin(ωt)​

children.value: The speed will be maximized when

children.html: sin⁡(ωt)=1or−1\sin(\omega t)=1\quad \textrm{or} -1sin(ωt)=1or−1

children.value: . So, the maximum speed will be:

children.html: ∣v∣=Aω∣v∣=A(k1+k2)m∣v∣=(0.1m)(2400Nm+3480Nm)30kg∣v∣=1.4m/s\begin{align*} |v|&=A\omega\\ |v|&=A\sqrt{\frac{(k_1+k_2)}{m}}\\ |v|&=(0.1 {\rm m})\sqrt{\frac{(2400 {\rm Nm}+3480 {\rm Nm})}{30 {\rm kg}}}\\ |v|&=1.4 {\rm m/s} \end{align*}∣v∣∣v∣∣v∣∣v∣​=Aω=Am(k1​+k2​)​​=(0.1m)30kg(2400Nm+3480Nm)​​=1.4m/s​

children.value: a. The only force that creates a torque on the masses is the restoring force from the twisting of the wire. The rotational dynamics version of Newton’s Second Law relates this torque to the angular acceleration,

children.html: Iα=−κθI\alpha=-\kappa\thetaIα=−κθ
III

children.value: is the moment of inertia of the rod. Rewriting
more explicitly as the second time derivative of the angle, we get:

children.html: Id2θdt2=−κθd2θdt2=−κIθ\begin{align*} I\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}&=-\kappa\theta\\ \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}&=-\frac{\kappa}{I}\theta\\ \end{align*}Idt2d2θ​dt2d2θ​​=−κθ=−Iκ​θ​

children.value: By inspection, we can see that the torsional pendulum is a simple harmonic oscillator, where

children.html: ω=κ/I\omega=\sqrt{\kappa/I}ω=κ/I​

children.value: . The period of the motion is therefore:

children.html: T=2πωT=2πIκ\begin{align*} T&=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}\\ T&=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{I}{\kappa}} \end{align*}TT​=ω2π​=2πκI​​​

children.value: We can rearrange this expression to get

children.html: T2=4π2Iκκ=4π2IT2\begin{align*} T^2&=\frac{4\pi^2I}{\kappa}\\ \kappa&=\frac{4\pi^2I}{T^2} \end{align*}T2κ​=κ4π2I​=T24π2I​​

L/2L/2L/2

children.value: is the distance from the mass to the axis of rotation. The moment of inertia for the two masses attached to the mass-less rod is:

children.html: I=2m(L2)2=mL22\begin{align*} I&=2m\left(\frac{L}{2}\right)^2=\frac{mL^2}{2}\\ \end{align*}I​=2m(2L​)2=2mL2​​

children.value: Putting this into our expression for

children.html: κ=2π2mL2T2\kappa=\frac{2\pi^2mL^2}{T^2}κ=T22π2mL2​

children.value: b. The two forces that provide torques for the small spheres are gravity and the force exerted by the twisting wire. Each of the small spheres will experience a force due to gravity from the nearest large sphere. At equilibrium, the force due to gravity on one of the small spheres is therefore:

children.html: Fg=GMmd2F_g=\frac{GMm}{d^2}Fg​=d2GMm​

children.value: Assuming that, at equilibrium, the force vector is perpendicular to the rod, the torque from one of the large spheres is just the force multiplied by the distance to the axis of rotation. Since there are two large spheres, each of which creates a torque on the pendulum, the total torque due to gravity is:

children.html: τg=2FgL2=FgL=GMmd2L\begin{align*} \tau_g&=2F_g\frac{L}{2}\\ &=F_gL\\ &=\frac{GMm}{d^2}L \end{align*}τg​​=2Fg​2L​=Fg​L=d2GMm​L​
τg\tau gτg

). We can use Newton’s second law for the pendulum to find an expression for

is constrained to be within that range, since the cosine function is periodic with a period
